news.title: An article
news.subtitle: 2.0 has arrived, wearing a new coat: Ajax.org
news.body:
The next generation. After the famous Star Trek series, which we all remember as a worthy and successful sequel, Javeline announces the immediate availability of Platform 2.0.
So, why 2.0 you ask? The reason is quite simple:
a) we used the 1.0 version internally extensively for a couple of large projects and
b) the core architecture has changed so dramatically since the last public release of 0.9.8, that 2.0 really is the only way to name it
Here\'s a basic overview of the most important changes:

All of the above is accompanied by the launch of the new Home for apf: Ajax.org. A brand-spanking new website dedicated entirely to the community and all of its content licensed under the CC. That means: please, spread the word! Start playing around with the package(s) and tell us what you think in the forums, share your experience and apf-related knowledge on the wiki!

This new version of apf is not so much a revolution, but the result of an evolution that has started almost eight years ago. Ruben joined the Ajax crowd before it was even there, developed the first publicly available XHR wrapper and that was the start of apf. Mike de Boer joined Ruben in August 2008 to aid in taking apf to the next level, bringing in the lessons learnt while developing the Web Application at technology startup eBuddy.com. Together, they redesigned the architecture and Lukasz then built further upon these building blocks with a handful of elements/ components.
